_emerg_resp.LEPCCoordinationReason: Emergency Response Coordination is performed with the local CUPA

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Mt. Whitney Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Mt. Whitney Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Mt. Whitney Cold Storage has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                 | Process Chemical            | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration          Anhydrous Ammonia             13,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM

regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

Exeter-Ivanhoe Citrus (Mt. Whitney Cold Storage) operates a commercial cold storage for a variety of fruit in Exeter, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(3) Precoolers
(5) Cold Storage Rooms

The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.

All control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly adjacent to each compressor room. A partial list of system components includes:

North Compressor Room
(3) Reciprocating compressors
(3) Oil separators
(2) High pressure receivers
(1) Main suction accumulator
(2) Evaporative condensers

South Compressor Room
(2) High pressure receivers

South Outdoor Compressor Area
(3) Upright compressors
(2) Evaporative condensers
(1) Main suction accumulator
(1) Oil pot

Precooler 1
(1) Accumulator
(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Precooler 2
(1) Accumulator
(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Precooler 3
(1) Accumulator
(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Cold Storage 1
(1) Accumulator
(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Cold Storage 2
(1) Accumulator
(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Cold Storage 3
(1) Accumulator
(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Cold Storage 4
(1) Accumulator
(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunke

r-mounted, spiral fin)

Cold Storage 5
(1) Accumulator
(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

The flooded system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator mounted behind the bunker wall. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to each high pressure receiver.

The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 

There are two ammonia detection systems located on the east exterior wall of the North Compressor Room. One detection system monitors the North Compressor Room. The sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate audible alarm and strobe. The second detection system monitors each refrigerated space (PC 1-3, CS 1-5). Each sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate audible alarm and strobe.

The ammonia refrigeration system at Exeter-Ivanhoe Citrus (Mt. Whitney Cold Storage) consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.  As such, the refrigeration system at Exeter-Ivanhoe Citrus (Mt. Whitney Cold S

torage) is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Mt. Whitney Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Mt. Whitney Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.
Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.  

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Mt. Whitney Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Mt. Whitney Cold Storage's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR §3220
- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR §1910.38

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with

the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Mt. Whitney Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Mt. Whitney Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Mt. Whitney Cold Storage's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Mt. Whitney Cold Storage's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Mt. Whitney Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.
In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Mt. Whitney Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Mt. Whitney Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Mt. Whitney Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Mt. Whitney Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and pu
